channel.title: Quick question (even newer question w/poll)
channel.description:
[size=small][s]Is this a bad method name?
[font=arial]create2DSpriteIn3DWorld[/font][/s][font=arial]
[s]I cant' think of a name for a class that represents a 2D sprite in the game that is used for objects like grass, torches, fire, trees, and just basic things that normally require lots of polygons for a 3D model. It isn't a GameObject because I use that for 3D objects, I was thinking "Detail" but I swear there's another word for it.[/s][/font]
TL;DR : Name for a class that represents a 2D sprite for an object.[/size]
I just remembered that games use crossed 2D polygons in place of billboarding polygons.
Crossed 2D polygons (if my wording isn't correct): [url=http://www.minecraftguides.org/blocks/tallGrass.png]http://www.minecraftguides.org/blocks/tallGrass.png[/url]
Which do you prefer?

item.title: Quick question (even newer question w/poll)
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Billboard and sprite are synonyms, at least according to Wikipedia (#1). In that case BillboardSprite would essentially be the same as SpriteSprite.

I would use Billboard as the name of the class or interface. It could implement or extend Sprite. But, obviously, the decision is all yours.

#1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sprite_(computer_graphics)#Synonyms

Read full topic

item.title: Quick question (even newer question w/poll)
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:13, topic:546916”][quote author=Limits link=topic=665813.msg4451319#msg4451319 date=1411601411]

A Billboard is a sprite that faces the camera at all times. It’s essentially a texture mapped to a (usually rectangular) polygon.

Yeah, so what should I call the class that represents that?
[/quote]
Billboard, BillboardGraphic, BillboardSprite, etc?

BillboardSprite would be essential if you had abstraction in that design of yours i.e. extends/implements Sprite[/quote]
BillboardSprite sounds good because, like you said, I do have abstraction in my design.

Read full topic

A Billboard is a sprite that faces the camera at all times. It’s essentially a texture mapped to a (usually rectangular) polygon.
[/quote]

BillboardSprite would be essential if you had abstraction in that design of yours i.e. extends/implements Sprite

item.title: Quick question (even newer question w/poll)
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“Limits, post:8, topic:546916”][quote author=Tutorial link=topic=665813.msg4451147#msg4451147 date=1411445595]

[quote author=Limits link=topic=665813.msg4451145#msg4451145 date=1411445176]

Is this a bad method name?

[size=11px][font=monaco]create2DSpriteIn3DWorld[/font][/size]
[/quote]depends on what it does???
[/quote]pretty sure its something to do with collision checking for clipping of scene objects in the player’s viewport

Nope, all it does is it creates a polygon and applys an npc texture to it and ‘spawns’ it at the given location.

It would seem that this suggests you have bad habits of clustering blocks of code together, but other than that, I see nothing wrong with it.

Sorry but what does that mean? Are you saying that I should make a separate method for spawning and a separate method for creating the polygon?

My answer to that question would depend on the scope of the application; however, in most of my applications I would separate things like rendering and spawning.

Yeah i get what you’re saying. In this instance, im creating the polygons at the given location. How else do you think it should be done?[/quote]
It’s completely fine the way you are doing it. It would just seem like a name you would use if you had multiple methods relating to the same thing, such as:

create3DSpriteIn3DWorld
create3DSpriteIn2DWorld

It would seem appropriate to use the very specific naming then, as it might be a vital component to the rendering process. But then again, there are several factors you have to take into consideration, such as:

[ul][li]Application scope[/li]
[li]Parameters - (are the methods going to do essentially the same thing, but require different formulas); such as render(Shape polygon) or render(Shape ngon); both obviously render shapes, but the design pattern for doing so would be different. This would allow you to pass an argument inside of another method based on the required shape.[/li]
[li]Object-orientation - it would definitely benefit you more in the end to think of all of the components of a given object, rather than thinking of it as one whole thing.[/li][/ul]

Read full topic
